event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_LatinoStudies
event.summary: Call for Papers, A Special Issue of The Global South: Interoceanic Diasporas and The Panama Canal's Centennial
event.description: Interoceanic Diasporas and The Panama CanalÂ¿s Centennial-Call for Papers: A Special Issue of The Global South Edited by Claudia Milian and Ifeoma Kiddoe Nwankwo In light of the ensuing centennial of the U.S. construction of the Panama Canal (1903-1914), this special volume reconsiders this interoceanic waterway as a lived space whose academic correspondence exceeds U.S. Latin American relations and brings in, hand in hand, Caribbean, African American, Latino and Latina, and Afro-Latino perspectives. This Special Issue of The Global South is scheduled for publication in Spring 2013. Please send a working title, abstract of 300-500 words, and a brief biographical note by 30 November 2011 to: panamacanalcentennial@gmail.com. Completed submissions are due on 1 May 2012. Essays should be 25-35 double-spaced pages long and follow the MLA style.

In collaboration with the Office of the Dean for Undergraduate Education, the Office of Global Strategy and Programs (OGSP), and the Research in Practice Program (RIPP), the Duke Center for Civic Engagement (DCCE) provides Civic Summer Research Fellowships to select Duke undergraduate students to translate and deepen their prior civic engagement experience into research projects or research-enriched practice directed toward civic challenges anywhere in the world. |

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp__ArtsandSciences_CenterforDocumentaryStudies
event.summary: Exhibition: Full Color Depression: First Kodachromes from America's Heartland

values.text: ep89 for Center for Documentary Studies (CDS) (agrp__ArtsandSciences_CenterforDocumentaryStudies)

event.description: "Full Color Depression: First Kodachromes from America's Heartland," runs from January 23-July 23. There will be a curator's talk on April 19, and the prints will be auctioned to the public on June 21. The exhibit features stunning large-scale prints of rare color photos taken by the famous Depression-era Farm Security Administration photography team. We all know the iconic B&W images taken by the FSA team--photographers like Dorothea Lange and Walker Evans. These color images, most not seen for more than 50 years, bring the era to life in a wholly unexpected way.

event.description: The Duke Center for Civic Engagement calls for proposals from faculty and staff to lead Civic Engagement Studios, a small interdisciplinary group of faculty, staff, students, and non-Duke community partners who will collaboratively study a civic challenge over an academic year, integrating the study with an ongoing or newly-designed course. At the end of the year, each Studio will present in a public forum an innovative solution or action-plan (in any format Â¿ video, art, performance, paper, proposal, online resource, etc.) that addresses the civic challenge on which it focused.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_MiddleEastStudiesCenter
event.summary: Photo Exhibit: Poetic Portraits of a Revolution: Arab Springs

values.text: , Duke Islamic Studies Center and Duke University Union (DUU)
kjj1 for Duke University Middle East Studies Center (agrp_MiddleEastStudiesCenter)

location.address: Bryan Center Louise Jones Brown Gallery
location.creator: /principals/users/public-user

event.description: "Poetic Portraits of a Revolution" includes photojournalistic imagery and poetic reflections of the struggle for self-determination in Egypt and Tunisia. During a time of transformative events, four young artists set out on a two-month journey to capture stories and images of the people behind the social movements and convey them through their art. This exhibit showcases some of the still shot depictions of both struggle and everyday life in both countries. The presentation seeks to humanize the revolutions by placing the focus on the people who drove them and the emotions that lie behind such powerful movements for change.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp__ArtsandSciences_CenterforDocumentaryStudies
event.summary: Exhibit: "When Janey Comes Marching Home: Portraits of Women Combat Veterans"

values.text: ep89 for Center for Documentary Studies (CDS) (agrp__ArtsandSciences_CenterforDocumentaryStudies)

event.description:
"When Janey Comes Marching Home" includes a series of forty large-scale color photographic portraits and accompanying oral histories of women who served in combat zones in Iraq and Afghanistan. The exhibit, and a book of the same name (2010, University of North Carolina Press), is a collaboration between photographer Sascha Pflaeging and author Laura Browder, a professor of English at Virginia Commonwealth University.
In taking the photos, Pflaeging said he was interested in "documenting these women visually while the situation is still present, their feelings and emotions still raw and very real." The resulting portraits, and accompanying text, convey stories that are by turns moving, comic, heartbreaking, and thought-provoking.

event.summary: The Puerto Rican Disapora: Photographs by Frank Espada
event.description:
The Puerto Rican Disapora: Photographs by Frank Espada
Frank Espada's black-and-white gelatin silver prints document the rural and the urban experience of Puerto Rican migrants to the United States in the 1970s and 1980s. The Libraries recently acquired Espada's papers, a rich resource on social activism, migration, and civil rights in the 20th century. Start: January 16, 2012 | End: July 2012 | Rubenstein Gallery

event.description: Call 684-3136, option 1 to schedule an appointment at this mobile location or contact our office to set up an appointment, held at the LFL office, on a day more convenient for you. This is a free, confidential health assessment. Spend approximately 30 minutes with a LIVE FOR LIFE nurse and discover all the positive health habits you have...plus develop strategies for those you may want to change. HealthCheck measures your cholesterol, blood pressure, blood glucose (if at risk), weight, and body mass index. A computerized report provides feedback on your current health measures and health practices. A nurse will help you get started on small changes to improve your health. Duke employees eligible for health care benefits may participate annually on work time.

event.description: Mr. Paul McKellips, Executive Vice-President for the Foundation for Biomedical Research (FBR) traces the 30 year decline in public support for the use of animals in research and outlines the rise and exploits of the Animal Rights Movement in both mainstream media and underground terrorism. Contrasted to the Animal Rights movement, Mr. McKellips reveals how positive, assertive media messaging that features biomedical research increases public support for the use of animals in research. He will also be available for a book signing of his novel "Uncaged" after the seminar.

Lunch provided at NOON Talk begins at 12:15PM
This talk explores the transformation of liver from an unpopular food to the mainstay of a healthy diet through the 1960s and 1970s, and places it within the broader context of therapeutic nutrition in the middle decades of the twentieth century.
Susan E. Lederer, PhD is the Robert Turell Professor in History of Medicine and Bioethics at the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health and chairs the Department of Medical History and Bioethics.

The seeds of the CSB were nurtured by regular open meetings that interleave research presentations with tutorials and journal clubs. event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_SSRI
event.summary: SSRI~ Workshop: Using Excel to organize and analyze information and data and to present findings

values.text: , Vice Provost for Interdisciplinary Studies and Libraries
cooper for Social Science Research Institute (SSRI) (agrp_SSRI)

event.description: This workshop provides an overview of ways Excel can be used to structure and even analyze data and to create presentations. It starts with examining basic tools and functions in Excel (including ways that Excel can be used to manage textual data, to combine or divide data cells and sources, and to perform calculations such as sum, average, minimum, and maximum). It then proceeds to an overview of how to sort and transpose data and create graphs and tables. Finally, it reviews how to perform basic statistical operations, including counts, frequencies, and even simple linear regressions, in Excel.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp__ArtsandSciences_SlavicEurasianStudies
event.summary: Labor in the Workers' State: The Soviet Origins of the Lamaze Method of Childbirth

values.text: Paula Michaels Associate Professor of History University of Iowa
db103 for Slavic and Eurasian Studies (agrp__ArtsandSciences_SlavicEurasianStudies)

event.description:
In the 1970s, Lamaze became a household word in the United States, as couples sought to bear children with less reliance on drugs to relieve pain. Also known as psychoprophylaxis, the Lamaze method relied on patterned breathing, conscious relaxation, prenatal education about the physiology of labor and birth, and massage in the hopes of avoiding or reducing resort to pharmacological pain relief. Few know, however, that psychoprophylaxis originated in Soviet Union in the late 1940s. At the intersection of the histories of medicine, gender, and the Cold War, the history of Soviet psychoprophylaxis well illustrates the plasticity and context sensitivity of meaning in medical practice.
Paula Michaels is Associate Professor of History at the University of Iowa. With a focus on Russian, Soviet, and Central Asian history, MichaelsÂ¿ research is primarily situated at the intersection of medicine and politics.

event.description: The Undergraduate Conduct Board (UCB) is a pool of students, faculty and staff who are selected/appointed to hear referred cases of potential violations of university policy. A three- or five-member panel, chaired by a student, hears each case. The Board has the ability to issue any sanction available through the undergraduate disciplinary process for a finding of responsibility, including suspension or expulsion. Rising juniors and seniors who have a commitment to honesty, fairness, respect, and accountability are invited to attend this information session to learn about the application and selection process for membership on the Board for the 2012-13 academic year.

event.summary: Exhibition: "Alexander Calder and Contemporary Art: Form, Balance, Joy"

values.text: dheinema for Nasher Museum of Art (agrp_NasherMuseumofArt)

event.description: This groundbreaking exhibition pairs 34 masterworks by Alexander Calder with the work of seven contemporary artists whose practices are bound to Calder's legacy as a modern sculptor. This is the first exhibition to explore Calder's significance for an emerging generation of sculptors, reconsidering his influence and innovation through a presentation of his own work alongside the work of contemporary artists. Admission to "Alexander Calder and Contemporary Art" is $10 for adults ($15 with guided tour), $5 for children 7 to 17, and free for children 6 and under. Admission is free for Duke students (on same day of admission, one per I.D.) and for Nasher Museum members (two free tickets per day per membership). Admission is $5 for Duke students in advance, $5 for non-Duke students, $5 for faculty and staff with a Duke ID and $5 for Duke Alumni Association members with an ID card. Closed Monday.

event.description: College offers students an opportunity both for academic learning and for learning life lessons from roommates and mentors. As Duke's dean of undergraduate education, Steve Nowicki is responsible for leading and coordinating all aspects of undergraduate life, inside and outside the classroom. event.summary: NGOs, The Cold War and the Idea of Civil Society

values.text: cl228 for Duke Human Rights Center (DHRC) (agrp_JHFC_DukeHumanRightsCenter)

event.description:
Mark Mazower, author, history professor and director of the Center for International History at Columbia University, will deliver a talk suggesting new historical frameworks within which to understand the emergence of NGOs and their role in international aid activism. He is the author of seven books, including the Duff Cooper Prize winning Salonica City of Ghosts: Christians, Muslims and Jews, 1430-1950, and the Los Angeles Times Book Prize for History winning HitlerÂ¿s Empire: Nazi Rule in Occupied Europe. Mazower is currently working on a history of internationalism, and his articles on history and current affairs appear regularly in the Financial Times, the Guardian, London Review of Books, The Nation and The New Republic.
Light lunch will be served. RSVP to rights@duke.edu.

His expertise and career have spans operations, product management, sales, and customer service. Currently the Managing Director of Global Transaction Services for Citibank, Mr. Ladany will share about his experience in the finance field. Learn from an expert on what it means to be in finance, beyond investment banking. Bio: John Ladany, Managing Director with Citibank. Mr. Ladany graduated with a BS in Accounting from Duke. He earned an MBA from the Darden School at the University of Virginia in 1984. Since then he has spent 27 years in commercial banking, almost exclusively with transaction services. event.summary: SSRI/DuPRI Seminar Series~Exposure to Violence During Childhood is Associated with Telomere Erosion from 5 to 10 Years of Age: A Longitudinal Study

values.text: Idan Shalev, Duke Psychology and Neuroscience
bv19 for Social Science Research Institute (SSRI) (agrp_SSRI)

event.description: There is increasing interest in discovering mechanisms that mediate the effects of childhood stress on late-life disease morbidity and mortality. Previous studies have suggested one potential mechanism linking stress to cellular aging, disease, and mortality in humans: telomere erosion. We examined telomere erosion in relation to childrenÂ¿s exposure to violence, a salient early-life stressor which has known long-term consequences for well-being and is a major public health and social-welfare problem.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_LatinoStudies
event.summary: Beyond Words: Language(s) and Learning Mathematics
event.description:
Beyond Words: Language(s) and Learning Mathematics George Watts Hill Alumni Center- Alumni Hall 1
Language is an important aspect of learning in mathematics classrooms. Whether students are speaking one language or two, learning and teaching involve communication. While questions about language and learning mathematics are particularly important to consider for students who are bilingual or learning English, they are also relevant to all mathematics learners. Research in mathematics education has explored how learners participate in mathematical discourse and research in sociolinguistics has examined how bilingual learners use two languages. This talk summarizes what this research says about how students communicate mathematically and how students use two languages.
Read more about Dr. Judit Moschkovich: http://education.ucsc.edu/faculty/singleton.php?&singleton=true&cruz_id=jmoschko

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_Libraries
event.summary: To Free a Family: The Journey of Mary Walker

values.text: , History, African and African American Studies (AAAS) and Graduate Liberal Studies

event.description: What was it like for a mother to flee slavery, leaving her children behind? Sydney Nathans, professor emeritus of history and author of "To Free a Family: The Journey of Mary Walker" (forthcoming, Harvard UP), tells the remarkable story of Mary Walker, a slave who fled North Carolina in 1848 for refuge in the north and spent the next seventeen years trying to recover her family. In recreating her journey, Nathans gives voice to a hidden epic of emancipation and an untold story of the Civil War era. Reception to follow. Copies of the book will be available for sale.

event.summary: Arab Springs: Revolution and Repression Conference

values.text: Duke University Middle East Studies Center
ks242 for Duke University Middle East Studies Center (agrp_MiddleEastStudiesCenter)

location.address: Bryan Center Von Canon Room B
location.creator: /principals/users/public-user

event.description: The Duke University Middle East Studies Center (DUMESC), in collaboration with the Center for the Study of the Middle East and Muslim Civilizations at UNC-Chapel Hill (CCSMEMC), has organized an interdisciplinary conference, Arab Springs: Revolution and Repression, that will explore the questions raised by the revolutionary uprisings, questions that are relevant well beyond the Arab world, as to what kind of "other world," politically and economically, might be possible at this historical moment. The conference will also address some of the artistic, technological, visual, and media dimensions of these struggles and transformations, including slogans, graffiti, poetry, cartoons, and songs, as well as the circuits of state controlled television, al-Jazeera, Facebook, Youtube, Twitter, and texting. Conference participants will include academic experts, activists, Ph.D. student researchers, cartoonists, poets, and other artists.
event.cost: Free; registration required. CONFERENCE IS FULL AND REGISTRATION IS CLOSED.

event.summary: Acing Client Service: Developing and Maintaining Superior Client Relations
event.description: Developing and effectively servicing your clients are, and always will be, two essential aspects of great lawyering. In fact, a full 89% of Am Law 200 firms recently characterized strong client relationships as "critical" to their success. Please join John DeGroote (Law '90), former General Counsel of BearingPoint, Inc. and current Liquidating Trustee of the BearingPoint, Inc. Liquidating Trust, and Sachin Bansal (Trinity '05, Law '08), a litigation associate at McKool Smith, P.C., to learn how to develop superior client relationships, even when some clients are requesting deep discounts and refusing to pay for work by first and second year associates. Dinner will be served, and an RSVP is required. To RSVP or for more information, email Alan Dickinson at dickinson@law.duke.edu, subject line "Client Service RSVP." Sponsored by the Career & Professional Development Center.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp__ArtsandSciences_Music
event.summary: Film Screening: An Encounter with Simone Weil

values.text: , Franklin Humanities Institute (FHI) and Art, Art History & Visual Studies

event.description: "An Encounter with Simone Weil" is an award-winning documentary directed by Julia Haslett and scored by Daniel Thomas Davis (Provost's Postdoctoral Fellow in the Department of Music). The screening, a sneak preview just before the film's theatrical opening in New York, will be followed by a Q&A with the filmmaker and composer. The film tells the story of French philosopher, activist, and mystic, Simone Weil (1909-1943), a woman Albert Camus described as "the only great spirit of our time." On her quest to understand Simone Weil, filmmaker Julia Haslett confronts profound questions of moral responsibility both within her own family and the larger world. Co-sponsored by the Franklin Humanities Institute, Duke Human Rights Center, Program for Arts of the Moving Image, and Audiovisualities Working Group.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_PrattSchool_Vtg

values.text: , Computer Science and Pratt School of Engineering

event.description: Remote Sensing of the Venice Lagoon and its Watershed, presented by Sonia Silvestri with Earth and Ocean Sciences, NSOE...........The Venice lagoon (Italy) is one of the largest lagoons in Europe, with a high environmental and socio-economic significance, also linked to the historical and cultural value of the city of Venice. In this presentation, remote sensing is used to look at the spatial and temporal variability of some environmental processes and to provide a visualization of such variability. Remote sensing facilitates the acquisition of spatial data and the interpretation of its space-time properties, providing access to the geometric patterns that can not be obtained using point measurements, particularly in a dynamic environment such as a coastal lagoon. Applications on the Venice lagoon watershed, where aquifer pollution may have fundamental impacts on the water quality of the lagoon, will also be presented.

event.description:
Jummah is held every Friday at 12:45 PM in York Room during the "academic year". This is the primary service for Duke students. The York Room is located in Gray building on the second floor of the Divinity School Library. It is accessible by entering the Divinity School Library from the first floor, or from a separate entry on the second floor. After prayer services, the community gathers together to socialize over lunch offered by Muslim Life at Duke. Jummah on West is a wonderful way to catch up with friends and meet new members to the Duke Muslim community.
Jummah at Duke North Hospital, too:
Jummah is held every Friday at 1:30 PM throughout the "entire year" in the Sixth Floor Chapel at Duke Hospital North. This service serves as an alternate to the one on West for those who cannot make the 12:45 time or for those who work or study closer to the hospital.

values.text: Surviving the Zombie Apocalypse: Winter Workshops with the Duke Campus Farm

event.description:
We don't know when or where or how it will begin, but we know this: the rise of the living dead will forever change the world we inhabit. With the power grid down, global trade halted, and brain-loving zombies roaming the countryside, you'll need the hard skills to thrive off the grid. That's why this Winter the Duke Campus Farm and Students for Sustainable Living are offering a series of hands-on workshops. All are welcome.
Cheese-making: Life without cheese is hard to imagine. Join us as we learn to make delicious cheeses like mozzarella and various hard cheeses. RSVP Required here: http://dcfcheesemaking.eventbrite.com/

values.text: aw122 for Master of Engineering Management Program (MEMP) (agrp_PrattSchool_MEMP)

event.description:
Charelle Lewis, MEMP alumna and PMI certified IT Project Manager for GlaxoSmithKline, will speak at the MEMP seminar this week. Charelle began her career in the IT Development Program at GSK. While in this program, she gained experience in several Professional IT roles including positions as Business Analyst, Process Improvement Analyst and Project Manager. She also earned her Six Sigma Certification.
Charelle transitioned from the development program in 2008 and began working in the Strategy, Architecture and Information Group in North America Pharma IT (NAPIT). In this role she has served as the Program Administrator for the NAPIT Innovation Team, founded and chaired GSKÂ¿s Global IT Innovation Committee, and Co-Founded the Early Career Network for GSKÂ¿s Research Triangle Park campus. She currently serves as the Program Manager for the Â¿eDetailÂ¿ initiate which will deliver an iPad Application to the US Sales Force. During her 7 year tenure at GSK, Charelle has earned a Master of Engineering Management Degree from Duke University.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_DukePerformances
event.summary: Workshop Reading: Fiasco Theater - 'Measure for Measure' by William Shakespeare
event.description:
Founded in 2007, this six-person company is already renowned for its dynamic, actor-focused style and lapidary productions of Shakespeare, whose elaborate romance Cymbeline sings out clearly in Fiasco's hands. During a swift-moving 150 minutes of witty music and swashbuckling action, the "lucid, modest performances let the comedy, poignancy, and unlikely magic surface" (NY Times).
Cymbeline is just the beginning of Fiasco's two-week residency with Duke Performances, where they also develop Shakespeare's Measure for Measure at Sheafer before giving two workshop readings in the intimate black-box theater. Get behind the scenes with an ascendant young company celebrated for its resourcefulness and dramatic brio.
In residence January 24 through February 11.
Fiasco Theater Company is a co-presentation of Duke Performances and Duke Theater Studies.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_DukePerformances
event.summary: Workshop Reading: Fiasco Theater - 'Measure for Measure' by William Shakespeare
event.description:
Founded in 2007, this six-person company is already renowned for its dynamic, actor-focused style and lapidary productions of Shakespeare, whose elaborate romance Cymbeline sings out clearly in Fiasco's hands. During a swift-moving 150 minutes of witty music and swashbuckling action, the "lucid, modest performances let the comedy, poignancy, and unlikely magic surface" (NY Times).
Cymbeline is just the beginning of Fiasco's two-week residency with Duke Performances, where they also develop Shakespeare's Measure for Measure at Sheafer before giving two workshop readings in the intimate black-box theater. Get behind the scenes with an ascendant young company celebrated for its resourcefulness and dramatic brio.
In residence January 24 through February 11.
Fiasco Theater Company is a co-presentation of Duke Performances and Duke Theater Studies.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_DukePerformances
event.summary: Ciompi Quartet Concert #3 (with Borromeo String Quartet)
event.description: HAYDN: String Quartet No. 2 in C Major, Op. 20, No. 2 GEORGE ENESCU: Octet for Strings in C Major, Op. 7 (with the Borromeo String Quartet) MENDELSSOHN: Octet for Strings in E-flat Major, Op. 16 (with the Borromeo String Quartet) ### For more than 40 years, the Ciompi Quartet has been Duke's steadfast resident chamber ensemble, interpreting both ageless repertory and bracing new music with colloquial warmth and musicality. They return with as exciting and substantial a season as we have seen from them in recent years. Season highlights include classic quartets by Haydn, DvorÃ¡k, Shostakovich, and Beethoven; collaborations with Leeds International Piano Competition winner Ian Hobson and the top-class Borromeo String Quartet, and the world premiere of a new quartet by Smith College professor Donald Wheelock. In a season full of extraordinary international chamber music, the Ciompi reminds us of the staggering talent nurtured right here in Durham.

event.summary: Break the Silence TWLOHA Benefit Concert
event.description:
TWLOHA - Duke and Sigma Nu Face Your Challenges present BREAK THE SILENCE, a benefit concert intended to encourage people to shatter the silence surrounding mental illness and challenge the stigmas that cause people to hide their struggles. All proceeds from the concert will be donated to To Write Love On Her Arms, a mental health nonprofit that exists to provide hope and help to people struggling with depression, addiction, self injury, and suicide. TWLOHA also invests directly into treatment and recovery. 50% of proceeds will be invested directly into our local community to impact mental health research and care in the Triangle area. Performances by headliner Go Radio, Voted Most Random, and Point Break. It's awesome music for an awesome cause! *Fulltime Duke Students with valid ID are eligible for a free ticket to this event if needed. Inquiries must be made in person at the Duke Box Office.
**Please arrive early. Late seating restrictions may be in effect.**

event.summary: Screen/Society--Cine-East Series--"Profound Desires of the Gods"

values.text: , Asian Pacific Studies Institute (APSI) and Asian & Middle Eastern Studies (AMES)
hml2 for Program in Arts of the Moving Image (AMI) (agrp_ArtsandSciences_FilmVideoDigitalProgram)

event.description: PROFOUND DESIRES OF THE GODS (Shohei Imamura, 1968, 173 min, Japan, Japanese w/ English subtitles, Color, DVD) -- The culmination of Shohei Imamura's extraordinary examinations of the fringes of Japanese society throughout the 1960s, PROFOUND DESIRES OF THE GODS was an 18-month super-production which failed to make an impression at the time of its release, but has since risen in stature to become one of the most legendary albeit least seen Japanese films of recent decades. Presenting a vast chronicle of life on the remote Kurage Island, the film centers on the disgraced, superstitious, interbred Futori family and the Tokyo engineer sent to supervise the creation of a new well - an encounter which leads to both conflict and complicity in strange and powerful ways. A tragic view of a passing epoch that teeters on the edge of grotesque farce, Imamura's merciless gaze combines with spectacular color CinemaScope photography to create a mythic saga convulsing with earthly impulses.

Ally Network members receive this card to place outside their office or residence hall room to indicate their support. Consider signing up for an Ally Network training session today!
The Ally Network provides an avenue through which straight-identified allies and LGBT people can actively express their affirmation of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people. Ally Network members are identified by displaying the Ally symbol (sign, button, magnet) and thus signify that their space is safe to talk about LGBT issues and that students and employees can be "out" or reveal their sexual orientation or gender identity.

event.description: LITTLE TOWN OF BETHLEHEM (Jim Hanon, 2010, 75 min, Palestine & Israel, English & Arabic w/ English subtitles, Color, DVD) -- LITTLE TOWN OF BETHLEHEM shares the gripping story of how three men born into the cycle of violence in the Holy Land have chosen to risk everything to bring peace through nonviolence. Sami and Ahmad are Palestinians; one is a Christian, the other a Muslim; and Yonatan is an Israeli Jew. Each finds inspiration in the words and actions of Martin Luther King Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi, and they struggle together to discover a common humanity through non-violent action. Their story brings fresh hope to the ongoing conflict between Palestine and Israel, while taking a stand against violence throughout the world. -- Discussion to follow!

event.summary: Live For Life HealthCheck @ Radiology Duke "South" Clinic 2E Room 24236
event.description: Call 684-3136, option 1 to schedule an appointment at this mobile location or contact our office to set up an appointment, held at the LFL office, on a day more convenient for you. This is a free, confidential health assessment. Spend approximately 30 minutes with a LIVE FOR LIFE nurse and discover all the positive health habits you have...plus develop strategies for those you may want to change. HealthCheck measures your cholesterol, blood pressure, blood glucose (if at risk), weight, and body mass index. A computerized report provides feedback on your current health measures and health practices. A nurse will help you get started on small changes to improve your health. Duke employees eligible for health care benefits may participate annually on work time.

event.description: The Journal Club is a highly successful informal meeting for students, residents, fellows, and staff. There is no limitation to the breadth of topics discussed. All fellows are assigned a day in rotation on which they will prepare a detailed review of a current journal article. The articles are distributed in advance of each meeting, and each fellow selects a faculty discussant to provide insight. Most trainees find this type of interchange to be an effective means of education, and members of the Division rely on Journal Club as a continuing source of new and interesting findings. For more information, contact Michelle Harris at 919-684-6854.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_SOM_ClinDep_Medicine_Div_Endocrinology
event.description: This event takes place in Room 8262. The Fellows' Lecture Series is a basic science conference. The purpose is to instruct trainees in the basic biochemistry, physiology, and pathophysiology of the endocrine system. Subject areas have included molecular biology, immunology as related to endocrinology and metabolism, signal transduction pathways, biology of hormone receptors and principles of hormone action, biology of sexual development, reproductive endocrinology, endocrine aspects of sexual dysfunction, among other topics. Faculty lead the conferences, which are usually in a seminar/open discussion format allowing interaction between the fellows and the faculty speaker.

event.description: The Political Theory Working Group is pleased to announce its first meeting for Fall 2011. This year's theme is "Utopia, Dystopia, and the Problem of Technology." English Department co-conveners are Dr. Michael Moses and Dr. Kathy Psomiades are joined by Dr. Michael Gillespie from the Department of Political Science. Our format for the year will be to focus each of our evening discussions on a major science fiction film and brief theoretical readings; we will also suggest a second film for those who have the time and inclination. Please see the website to rsvp (and for more details).

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_Libraries
event.description: Google Refine is a tool for working with messy data. It allows you to detect and fix inconsistencies in your data, transform your data from one structure to another, and provides a simple way to understand patterns in your data. If you've ever faced the task of trying to harmonize names, ISBNs, or titles in a spreadsheet, Refine provides an appealing way of dealing with these common challenges. In this hands-on class, we'll explore how Refine can help with common data cleaning challenges. Please click on the "More Information" link and register to attend.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_SSRI
event.summary: SSRI~ Workshop: Introduction to Survey Research

values.text: , Vice Provost for Interdisciplinary Studies and Libraries
cooper for Social Science Research Institute (SSRI) (agrp_SSRI)

event.description: This workshop is designed for researchers new to survey research who are considering using an original survey to collect data. The workshop begins with a discussion of the advantages and opportunities that surveys can offer, as well as when surveys are not appropriate or beneficial for research projects and a quick overview of some alternative methods of data collection. It then provides an overview of the entire survey research process, including theoretical development, mode choice, questionnaire design, sampling, and maximizing response rate. Issues related to implementation and data management are also covered.

event.creator: /principals/users/agrp_SarahPDukeGardens

values.text: kab68 for Sarah P. Duke Gardens (agrp_SarahPDukeGardens)

event.description: Life on earth would not exist without water, yet we often take water for granted. Although the water on planet earth is constant, with none added or subtracted, it is also in constant motion; liquid, frozen, snow, vapor. As it moves around the earth it is contained as surface water, moving water, fresh water, ocean water. Each form acts differently and each form is essential for the entire cycle to work properly. Study water from an ecological perspective and gain a new appreciation for the wonders of the water planet. This 4-session class continues at the same time Feb. 28, March 6, and March 13.
event.cost: $150; $120 Gardens members and Duke staff and students

values.text: je62 for Center for LGBT Life (agrp_StudentAffairs_CenterforLGBTLife)

location.address: The Center for LGBT Life 2 West Union Building
location.creator: /principals/users/public-user

event.description:
Are you looking for LGBTQ women's community? Women Loving Women is a monthly meeting group for LGBTQ-identified women at Duke. Many LGBTQ women at Duke sometimes feel as though they are the only ones with such experiences, but this could not be farther from the truth! Join us monthly for a relaxed, engaging dialogue and dinner among fellow queer women, and an evening to discover a greater LGBTQ women's community at Duke.
In order to respect the individuality and personal decisions of each member, those who attend the monthly dialogues are asked not to discuss the participants of the group beyond the evening. Contact Janie Long (janie.long@duke.edu) with questions, concerns, or to learn more about the group.
